title: INFORMED CONSENT
value:
You are being asked to consider participating in a research study. A research study is a
way of gathering information on a treatment, procedure or medical device or to answer
a question about something that is not well understood.
This form explains the purpose of this research study, provides information about the
Medly application, the procedures involved, possible risks and benefits, and the rights of
participants.
Please read this form carefully and ask any questions you may have. You may have
this form and all information concerning the study explained to you. The study staff will
tell you if there are any study timelines for making your decision. Please ask the study
staff or one of the investigator(s) to clarify anything you do not understand or would like
to know more about. Make sure all your questions are answered to your satisfaction
before deciding whether to participate in this research study.
Participating in this study is your choice (voluntary). You have the right to choose not to
participate, or to stop participating in this study at any time.

title: INTRODUCTION
value:
You are being asked to consider participating in this study because you have been
diagnosed with heart failure (HF) and are currently being treated in hospital.

title: WHY IS THIS STUDY BEING DONE?
value:
Digital health interventions, including telemonitoring and mobile phone applications,
have been shown to allow patients to receive cohesive and well-coordinated care from
their home instead of a hospital setting. These applications make it possible for patients
to monitor their medical conditions (such as measuring blood pressure and weight),
track symptoms and receive automated instructions and medical care from their homes.
This can help patients take better care of themselves and gives their healthcare
providers (doctors or nurses) important information to base their decisions on.
The University Health Network (UHN) team has developed a smartphone-based
system, Medly, which allows for the telemonitoring of patients diagnosed with heart
failure. The Medly system includes an app that is loaded on a smartphone. Using the
appropriate wireless medical devices (such as blood pressure monitor and weight
scale), patients can monitor their condition and symptoms, get immediate feedback, and
automatically send data to their healthcare providers.
The purpose of this study is to determine whether patients are able to comply the Medly
application after discharge from a hospital and whether using the Medly system
improves patients’ self-care management and quality of life.
